newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: MOTOR RACING-VILLENEUVE OUT TO EXTEND WILLIAMS DOMINANCE.
newsitem.headline: MOTOR RACING-VILLENEUVE OUT TO EXTEND WILLIAMS DOMINANCE.

text.p: Jacques Villeneuve has fond memories of last year's second place finish in the Argentine Grand Prix as he tries to strengthen Williams' grip on motor racing at this week's race.
The 25-year-old Canadian heads his team's assault at the Oscar Galvez circuit in Buenos Aires, sharing the lead of the world drivers' title race with Briton David Coulthard of McLaren.
Villeneuve finished second in Argentina last year behind then team-mate Damon Hill, who also won in 1995 and who went on last year to lift the world crown.
Villeneuve, the red-hot pre-season favourite, will draw on last year's experience at this week's event.
"Last year, it was only my third Grand Prix race. But this year I'm looking forward to returning to Argentina with prior knowledge and experience of the circuit.
"It was not a bad weekend there last year and the car was pretty good. So, I've got good memories.

"The circuit is very modern. It is full of hairpins and chicanes so I think it is a great challenge. But this year's car is strong, very strong and the team are working very hard and well and I feel pretty confident. I must say a victory would be great"

Villeneuve's confidence is not entirely shared by team-mate Heinz-Harald Frentzen of Germany, yet to score a point this season. Last Friday he flew to England to attend critical talks at team headquarters aimed at resolving his early-season problems with the set up of his car.
"Without doubt, I am hoping to be in a better position in Argentina than I was in Brazil," he said after long talks with his engineers. "It just didn't seem to come together for me there.
"But I am confident about finding a good set-up in Argentina. I like the circuit at Buenos Aires, it reminds me of a go-kart track."
The tight, twisty and relatively small circuit was criticised last year for being too bumpy for Grand Prix cars but is believed to have been resurfaced since.
However, it is rarely used for racing and is expected to be a low-grip track which could require the cars to run with high downforce levels.

This may upset the established order and offer the Bridgestone tyre company, newly-arrived rivals to Goodyear, a chance to steal a march with the Arrows and Prost teams. In Sao Paulo, the Bridgestone-shod Prost of Oliver Panis finished third and a repeat performance could be delivered.
Villeneuve's chief challenge, however, is likely to come from the rapidly-improving Benetton team and in particular Frenchman Jean Alesi.
Alesi tested at Silverstone last week and the team will have a new front suspension system in Argentina.

Team-mate Gerhard Berger of Austria, second behind Villeneuve in Brazil, will also be strong despite the distractions of his father being imprisoned for fraud - unrelated to motor racing - and the birth in Lisbon last week of his third daughter.
The Ferrari and McLaren teams should also be reliable and quick with Michael Schumacher in particular likely to shine.
But it will be a difficult weekend for the new Stewart team, making their first visit to the track, and for Jordan with their two inexperienced drivers.
